description: Uploaded by https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/runbooks/-/jobs/6832796321 at Mon May 13 03:28:20 UTC 2024

panels.description: Error rates are a measure of unhandled service exceptions per second. Client errors are excluded when possible. Lower is better

seriesOverrides.alias: /6h Degradation SLO \(5% of monthly error budget\).*/
/1h Outage SLO \(2% of monthly error budget\).*/

targets.legendFormat: 6h Degradation SLO (5% of monthly error budget)
1h Outage SLO (2% of monthly error budget)

panels.title: logging Service Error Ratio

targets.expr:
sum (
  label_replace(
    vector(0) and on() (gitlab_service_errors:ratio_1h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="logging"}),
    "period", "na", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(1) and on() (gitlab_service_errors:ratio_5m{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="logging"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (14.4 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="logging"})),
    "period", "5m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(2) and on() (gitlab_service_errors:ratio_1h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="logging"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (14.4 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="logging"})),
    "period", "1h", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(4) and on() (gitlab_service_errors:ratio_30m{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="logging"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (6 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="logging"})),
    "period", "30m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(8) and on() (gitlab_service_errors:ratio_6h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="logging"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (6 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="logging"})),
    "period", "6h", "", ""
  )
)

panels.description: The operation rate is the sum total of all requests being handle for all components within this service. Note that a single user request can lead to requests to multiple components. Higher is busier.
panels.title: logging Service RPS - Requests per Second

panels.description: Saturation is a measure of what ratio of a finite resource is currently being utilized. Lower is better.
panels.title: Saturation

panels.content:
### Description

This cluster SLI monitors log index operations to GitLab's logging ELK instance.



### Observability Tools

* [üìñ Kibana: Monitoring Cluster logs](https://00a4ef3362214c44a044feaa539b4686.us-central1.gcp.cloud.es.io:9243/app/kibana#/discover?_a=(columns:!(log.level,message,elasticsearch.component),filters:!((meta:(index:'3fdde960-1f73-11eb-9ead-c594f004ece2',key:json.type,params:logging,type:phrase),query:(match:(json.type:(query:logging,type:phrase))))),index:'3fdde960-1f73-11eb-9ead-c594f004ece2')&_g=(time:(from:'${__from:date:iso}',to:'${__to:date:iso}')))

### Description

This SLI monitors fluentd log output and the number of output errors in fluentd.



### Observability Tools

panels.content:
### Observability Tools

* [Google Load Balancer](https://console.cloud.google.com/net-services/loadbalancing/details/http/ops-prod-proxy?project=gitlab-ops)
* [Stackdriver Logs: Loadbalancer Access Logs](https://console.cloud.google.com/logs/query;query=resource%2Elabels%2Eurl%5Fmap%5Fname%3D%22ops%2Dprod%2Dproxy%22%0Aresource%2Etype%3D%22http%5Fload%5Fbalancer%22;timeRange=PT30M?project=gitlab-ops)
* [Stackdriver Logs: Loadbalancer Access 5xx Logs](https://console.cloud.google.com/logs/query;query=httpRequest%2Estatus%3E%3D500%0Aresource%2Elabels%2Eurl%5Fmap%5Fname%3D%22ops%2Dprod%2Dproxy%22%0Aresource%2Etype%3D%22http%5Fload%5Fbalancer%22;timeRange=PT30M?project=gitlab-ops)

panels.content:
### Description

This SLI monitors pubsub subscriptions.



### Observability Tools

* [üìñ Kibana: Pubsubbeat logs](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/app/kibana#/discover?_a=(columns:!(kubernetes.host,json.message),filters:!((meta:(index:'c1ee6e20-fbf1-11ea-af41-ad80f197fa45',key:json.type,params:pubsubbeat,type:phrase),query:(match:(json.type:(query:pubsubbeat,type:phrase))))),index:'c1ee6e20-fbf1-11ea-af41-ad80f197fa45')&_g=(time:(from:'${__from:date:iso}',to:'${__to:date:iso}')))
* [üìà Kibana: Pubsubbeat requests](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/app/kibana#/visualize/create?type=line&indexPattern=c1ee6e20-fbf1-11ea-af41-ad80f197fa45&_a=(filters:!((meta:(index:'c1ee6e20-fbf1-11ea-af41-ad80f197fa45',key:json.type,params:pubsubbeat,type:phrase),query:(match:(json.type:(query:pubsubbeat,type:phrase))))),query:(language:kuery,query:''),vis:(aggs:!((enabled:!t,id:'1',params:(),schema:metric,type:count),(enabled:!t,id:'2',params:(drop_partials:!t,extended_bounds:(),field:'@timestamp',interval:auto,min_doc_count:1,scaleMetricValues:!f,timeRange:(from:'${__from:date:iso}',to:'${__to:date:iso}'),useNormalizedEsInterval:!t),schema:segment,type:date_histogram))))&_g=(time:(from:'${__from:date:iso}',to:'${__to:date:iso}')))

panels.title: Details

panels.description: Error rates are a measure of unhandled service exceptions per second. Client errors are excluded when possible. Lower is better

seriesOverrides.alias: /6h Degradation SLO \(5% of monthly error budget\).*/
/1h Outage SLO \(2% of monthly error budget\).*/

targets.legendFormat: 6h Degradation SLO (5% of monthly error budget)
1h Outage SLO (2% of monthly error budget)

panels.title: pubsubbeat SLI Error Ratio

targets.expr:
sum (
  label_replace(
    vector(0) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_1h{component="pubsubbeat",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="logging"}),
    "period", "na", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(1) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_5m{component="pubsubbeat",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="logging"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (14.4 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="pubsubbeat",monitor="global",type="logging"})),
    "period", "5m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(2) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_1h{component="pubsubbeat",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="logging"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (14.4 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="pubsubbeat",monitor="global",type="logging"})),
    "period", "1h", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(4) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_30m{component="pubsubbeat",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="logging"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (6 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="pubsubbeat",monitor="global",type="logging"})),
    "period", "30m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(8) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_6h{component="pubsubbeat",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="logging"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (6 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="pubsubbeat",monitor="global",type="logging"})),
    "period", "6h", "", ""
  )
)

### Description

panels.title: Details

panels.description: Network utilization
panels.title: fluentd-archiver Deployment: Network IO

panels.description: Network utilization
panels.title: fluentd-elasticsearch Deployment: Network IO

panels.description: Network utilization
panels.title: pubsubbeat Deployment: Network IO

panels.description:
Average CPU utilization per Node.

This resource measures all CPU across a fleet. If it is becoming saturated, it may indicate that the fleet needs horizontal or
vertical scaling. The metrics are coming from elasticsearch_exporter.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      avg by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard) (
        avg_over_time(elasticsearch_process_cpu_percent{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="logging"}[1m]) / 100
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: elastic_cpu component saturation: Average CPU Utilization per Node

panels.description:
Disk utilization per device per node.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, host) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      sum by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard, host) (
        (elasticsearch_filesystem_data_size_bytes{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="logging"} - elasticsearch_filesystem_data_free_bytes{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="logging"})
      )
      /
      sum by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard, host) (
        elasticsearch_filesystem_data_size_bytes{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="logging"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: elastic_disk_space component saturation: Disk Utilization Overall

panels.description:
JVM heap memory utilization per node.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, name) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      elasticsearch_jvm_memory_used_bytes{area="heap", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="logging"}
      /
      elasticsearch_jvm_memory_max_bytes{area="heap", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="logging"}
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: elastic_jvm_heap_memory component saturation: JVM Heap Utilization per Node

panels.description:
Average CPU per Node.

This resource measures all CPU across a fleet. If it is becoming saturated, it may indicate that the fleet needs horizontal or
vertical scaling. The metrics are coming from elasticsearch_exporter.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, name) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      avg_over_time(elasticsearch_process_cpu_percent{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="logging"}[5m]) / 100
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: elastic_single_node_cpu component saturation: Average CPU Utilization per Node

panels.description:
Disk utilization per device per node.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, name) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      (
        (
          elasticsearch_filesystem_data_size_bytes{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="logging"}
          -
          elasticsearch_filesystem_data_free_bytes{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="logging"}
        )
        /
        elasticsearch_filesystem_data_size_bytes{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="logging"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: elastic_single_node_disk_space component saturation: Disk Utilization per Device per Node

panels.description:
Utilization of each thread pool on each node.

Descriptions of the threadpool types can be found at
https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/modules-threadpool.html.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, name, exported_type) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      (
        avg_over_time(elasticsearch_thread_pool_active_count{exported_type!="snapshot", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="logging"}[5m])
        /
        (avg_over_time(elasticsearch_thread_pool_threads_count{exported_type!="snapshot", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="logging"}[5m]) > 0)
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: elastic_thread_pools component saturation: Thread pool utilization

panels.description:
Kubernetes containers are allocated a share of CPU. Configured using resource requests.

This is the amount of CPU that a container should always have available,
though it can briefly utilize more. However, if a lot of pods on the same
host exceed their requested CPU the container could be throttled earlier.

This monitors utilization/allocated requests over a 1 hour period, and takes
the 99th quantile of that utilization percentage in that period.
We want the worst case to be around 80%-90% utilization,
meaning we've sized the container correctly. If utilization is much higher than that
the container could already be throttled because the host is overused, if it
is much lower, then we could be underutilizing a host.

This saturation point is only used for capacity planning.
Containers that have a quota specified are excluded here and can be monitored using
the `kube_container_throttling` saturation component.
The burst utilization of a CPU is monitored and alerted upon using the
`kube_container_cpu_limit` saturation point.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    quantile by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
  0.99,
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      (
        sum by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
          rate(container_cpu_usage_seconds_total:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="logging"}[1h])
        )
        unless on(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
          container_spec_cpu_quota:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="logging"}
        )
      )
      /
      sum by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
        kube_pod_container_resource_requests:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", resource="cpu", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="logging"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_container_cpu component saturation: Kube Container CPU Utilization

panels.description:
Kubernetes containers can have a limit configured on how much CPU they can consume in
a burst. If we are at this limit, exceeding the allocated requested resources, we
should consider revisting the container's HPA configuration.

When a container is utilizing CPU resources up-to it's configured limit for
extended periods of time, this could cause it and other running containers to be
throttled.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      sum by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
        rate(container_cpu_usage_seconds_total:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="logging"}[5m])
      )
      /
      sum by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
        container_spec_cpu_quota:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="logging"}
        /
        container_spec_cpu_period:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="logging"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_container_cpu_limit component saturation: Kube Container CPU over-utilization

panels.description:
This uses the working set size from cAdvisor for the cgroup's memory usage. That may
not be a good measure as it includes filesystem cache pages that are not necessarily
attributable to the application inside the cgroup, and are permitted to be evicted
instead of being OOM killed.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      container_memory_working_set_bytes:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="logging"}
      /
      (container_spec_memory_limit_bytes:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="logging"} > 0)
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_container_memory component saturation: Kube Container Memory Utilization

panels.description:
Kube container throttling

A container will be throttled if it reaches the configured cpu limit for the
horizontal pod autoscaler. Or when other containers on the node are overutilizing
the the CPU.

To get around this, consider increasing the limit for this workload, taking
into consideration the requested resources.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    quantile by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
  0.99,
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      avg by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container)(
        rate(container_cpu_cfs_throttled_periods_total:labeled{container!="", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="logging"}[5m])
        /
        rate(container_cpu_cfs_periods_total:labeled{container!="", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="logging"}[5m])
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_container_throttling component saturation: Kube container throttling

panels.description:
The [Horizontal Pod Autoscaler](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/run-application/horizontal-pod-autoscale/)
automatically scales the number of Pods in a deployment based on metrics.

The Horizontal Pod Autoscaler has a configured upper maximum. When this
limit is reached, the HPA will not increase the number of pods and other
resource saturation (eg, CPU, memory) may occur.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, horizontalpodautoscaler, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_status_desired_replicas:labeled{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="logging", shard!~"database-throttled|elasticsearch|gitaly-throttled|urgent-authorized-projects|urgent-other", namespace!~"pubsubbeat"}
      /
      kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_spec_max_replicas:labeled{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="logging", shard!~"database-throttled|elasticsearch|gitaly-throttled|urgent-authorized-projects|urgent-other", namespace!~"pubsubbeat"}
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_desired_replicas component saturation: Horizontal Pod Autoscaler Desired Replicas

panels.description:
Open file descriptor utilization per instance.

Saturation on file descriptor limits may indicate a resource-descriptor leak in the application.

As a temporary fix, you may want to consider restarting the affected process.
 Lower is better.
panels.title: open_fds component saturation: Open file descriptor utilization per instance
